job_title: Direct Support Coordinator in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Their ACTUAL PRIORITY is resident care. They do not tolerate neglectful employees. Excellent place to work, grow, and excellent place to receive care.
cons: Live-in hours were difficult, but that's just the nature of the work.

job_title: Office Staff in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Great benefits, work environment is friendly and down-to-earth, and RSI truly tries their best to accommodate all sorts of things. They are very understanding, and committed to the residents and the staff. I truly enjoyed working with the people I worked with every day and it was nice to work in an environment that didn’t feel toxic.
cons: Pay can be low, but this IS a non-profit; they receive funding from the govt and have to budget that money properly. Plenty of opportunities to make more money, get promoted, and get bonuses. Group homes are sometimes poorly maintained, but the pandemic and lack of staff definitely caused this.

job_title: Work With Families and Individuals With Disabilities in Chapel Hill, NC

job_title: Warehouse Worker in Charlotte, NC

review_title: Solid concept. Poor team building. Not Honest.
job_title: Direct Support Coordinator in Durham, NC
pros: They are very client based. Their residents are undoubtedly very well cared for. There are areas for improvement but I would say the overall population of the residents at RSI are happy in their homes and are receiving a quality service. Their over all ambitions as a company are solid.
cons: Upper management and administration are power tripping, for lack of better word. I needed to be accommodated for my mental illness in the work place and they were completely unwilling to work with me. Actually no, they were willing to work with me but for such a short time that it seemed like a slap in the face to me. They often said things that ended up not being true From the application process on. If you don't have inordinate amounts of time to dedicate to this job I wouldn't suggest going for it. VERY rigorous hiring process. I would have expected more out of them from the image they project for themselves.

job_title: in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Not only do I whole-heartedly believe in the mission of RSI, but I love the culture of this company.  Because of the nature of the work that we do, we are able to bond as staff members because we are all here for the same reasons- to help our residents.  We are so lucky to be close to so many area colleges/universities and employ the 'best of the best'- students or recent graduates who are eager to gain hands-on experience.  I love working with other staff who care about the residents as much as I do.
cons: Many of the shifts (particularly on the weekends) are very long- but all the fun activities that happen on the weekends make the days go by fast!

job_title: Supervisor of Support Services in Chapel Hill, NC
pros:
RSI has conviction with their mission and vision.   RSI's individual services and support are exceptional and unparalleled.  I would not hesitate to have a loved one within their care.

For anyone seeking career advancement, RSI offers excellent opportunity for growth and progressive responsibility.
cons: RSI is a non-profit that is state and federally funded.  Funding for I/DD, MH and SA has been declining over a number of years, so it is fiscally challenging for all service providers within the field.

review_title: Rewarding work but not very good communication or dispersement of duties.
job_title: Direct Support Professional in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Great schedule! Monday through Friday with no weekends and 11/hr. It feels rewarding in the relationships you gain with the residents;you get attached.
cons: Can be strenuous work and they get upset when you ask for time off for a last minute emergency. The work seems to be pushed on 1 person in the group home,and sometimes you’re not treated the best by the individuals in the office as if they’re inferior to you and your job.

job_title: Accounts Payable/Payroll Specialist in Chapel Hill, NC
pros:
RSI has some of the friendliest, hardest-working people on staff that I have ever met. Every interaction I had in my position was pleasant for the most part, and the staff genuinely care about the residents as well as each other. As cheesy as it is to say, working here felt like working as part of a family rather than as though I was a number; RSI as a whole wants to see the success of its people.

Benefits package is nice. The 403(b) is not matching but I advise setting it up anyway because it is never too early to start saving for retirement. My direct supervisor was also very flexible about me taking days off and she worked to accommodate me when I needed assistance completing payroll in order to take a vacation. The company is very family-oriented and understanding in that respect, which is great. Overall, RSI has a wonderful community and positive vibes.
cons:
Too many people are involved in every project, which slows the decision-making process considerably. Meeting and committees should be used only when necessary, not for every change the company considers. It was also hard to receive feedback on performance unless something very negative happened; most people benefit from hearing what they are doing well, in addition to suggestions for improvement.

There is not much room for advancement in RSI in terms of career opportunities. The management is unlikely to change until they reach retirement age since they are so loyal to the company, but that means turnover is high since lower level employees are only staying long enough to get the experience added to their resume and then they are leaving for higher-paying work. Pay is also low, but that is expected with a non-profit organization. It's a great starting point from which to build your career.

job_title: Direct Support Professional (Full-Time) in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Working with the residents was a blast! They are some of the most honest, caring, amazing people I've ever met, even if working with them can be difficult at times. Every day a smile was put on my face by one resident or another. Most of my coworkers (at the ground level) were also great. It was just the management (or lack thereof) that got in the way.
cons:
The management was AWFUL. Even though the direct support professionals (basically the lowest position on the totem pole) do basically the hardest and most important work (the actual day-to-day ground work with the residents - the actual teaching of skills and coping mechanisms and handling of crisis situations) they hardly get any recognition for just how important their work is and not nearly enough compensation (including pay & benefits) for how hard & vital the job is. In my experience with RSI, the management rarely consulted the ground staff and seemed to make decisions in a bubble. 

Furthermore, the training was horribly inadequate and when I requested more/better training I was told that I should be able to figure things out on my own (like how to interact with unfamiliar residents in specific recurring situations) based on generalities given during the initial 2-day orientation session. This implies that there's a one-size-fits approach to supporting adults with developmental disabilities, which, if you've ever worked with adults with disabilities, you would know is simply false, if not disrespectful. The residents are unique individuals just like anyone else and should be treated as such. This SHOULD mean that if, as staff, you're going to have to interact with a particular resident in a recurring situation, you should be given adequate training for how to support them in that specific situation. This was not provided initially and when I asked for it to be provided, this negatively impacted my performance evaluation (which was over 6 months overdue to begin with, and referenced instances from my initial 3-month probationary period which no one had previously mentioned or addressed). And that's not even getting into the safety risks of lack of training with certain residents who have a tendency to become physically violent towards themselves and/or others if certain detailed procedures aren't followed properly.

A friend of mine who's moving back to the area and works in the field recently asked if I would recommend RSI as a place to work and my answer was an emphatic NO because of how awful the management was. At first I really liked working for RSI because, as mentioned above, I loved working with the residents, it was a reliable full time job with consistent hours (even if it meant getting up before dawn), and I could leave work at work and come home and still have a life. But the management got in the way of doing my job so often that I dreaded going in and eventually it started following me home. I would get home so exhausted and frustrated that I could barely do more than veg out in front of the tv for a few hours, eat dinner, and go to bed. So unfortunately I had to break my year-long contract (even though initially I could've seen myself staying indefinitely) and quit. It was an upsetting experience because I cared quite a lot about the residents and I miss them dearly half a year later. And what makes me even more sad is that I know I am not the only one who felt this way. Not only did I hear similar complaints made by my coworkers but RSI's horrid turnover rates should speak for themselves.

On a side note, I did work for one of the day programs (LO) which seemed to be the most poorly managed area of the company. So perhaps working in a different area wouldn't be quite as bad (independent living, for instance). Still, my experience was so bad that I would NEVER recommend RSI as a place to work. I wish I could say otherwise for the sake of the residents but I can't. Perhaps if your only looking to be an intern or volunteer the poor management wouldn't be so damaging. But the bottom line is: They don't treat the employees on the ground well which means ultimately they don't treat the residents well either since it's the ground staff that do the day-to-day work with the residents.

job_title: Direct Support Coordinator in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Excellent work environment,  supportive supervisors/directors. They provide bonuses yearly if funds are available. Good opportunity for growth if you have a associates/bachelors or good experience.  Residents are amazing, and working directly with them can be incredibly fun if you plan your days correctly!
cons: Salary is average for the field/for a non-profit. Long working shifts, especially on weekends. Holidays are usually required.

job_title: Direct Support Professional in Carrboro, NC
pros: This is a very rewarding position.  The work matters, and the company is very responsive to ideas from employees.  The schedule can be flexible, and there are opportunities for advancement.
cons: They are sometimes short staffed, and it can be difficult to provide the support the residents need.  Some of the work is very emotionally challenging.

job_title: Direct Support Professional in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Staff is mostly friendly, and focuses on work. Residents are taken care of very well, and staff is given extensive training from CPR, First Aid, to NCI.
cons: Pay is pretty low, for a high stress job. However it is social work so it's understandable.

Capability of moving up quickly in the company. 
AWESOME experience reference.
